abstract.p: Isolated sinus of Valsalva (SV) aneurysm is a rare condition that may arise in patients with congenital ventricular septal defects (VSD). Small VSDs are often left untreated because of high rate of spontaneous closure. However, complications such as aortic regurgitation and infective endocarditis may occur as complications of small VSDs. We present the case of a 19-year-old man with a history of VSD, who presented with Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis and a contained rupture of the SV into the right ventricle, which was successfully treated. In the light of this case, we believe that even small VSDs should be assessed regularly and treated before such drastic complications occur.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Isolated aneurysms of the sinus of Valsalva (SV) are rare conditions. 1 The etiology may be congenital or in association with syphilis, atherosclerosis, or endocarditis. 2 Congenital aneurysms are mostly found in the right coronary sinus (65%-85%), followed by the noncoronary sinus (10%-30%) and rarely in the left coronary sinus (1%-5%), 3 and account for 1% to 3% of all cardiac anomalies. 1 Other congenital abnormalities of the heart such as bicuspid aortic valve and ventricular septal defect (VSD) may be associated with these aneurysms. 4 We report a rare case of a long-standing VSD associated with a contained rupture of aneurysm of the right SV, associated with Staphylococcus aureus endocarditis and acute aortic regurgitation (AR).

sec.title: Case Presentation
sec.p: A 19-year-old man presented to the emergency department with fever and tachycardia. He was found to have a continuous central heart murmur grade 4/6. As a child he had been diagnosed with a perimembranous ventricular septal defect (PVSD), which was left untreated. His echocardiogram showed a 2-cm2 PVSD, an aneurysm of the right SV with vegetation, and possible rupture of the aneurysm into the right ventricle with a left-to-right shunt (Qp/Qs = 3:1, estimated by using two-dimensional echocardiography and spectral Doppler measurements), moderate to severe AR, and depressed left ventricular (LV) function with ejection fraction <30% (Figure 1). His blood tests showed elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and creatinine level and a low platelet count. He was treated with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to address native valve endocarditis.

caption.p: Long parasternal axis echocardiographic view showing (A) vegetation from the right aortic sinus protruding into the right ventricular outflow tract (arrow) and aneurysm of the right sinus of Valsalva communicating with the right ventricular outflow tract (dashed arrow).

sec.p: In view of his presenting symptoms, he was transferred to our center for an urgent operation. During the induction of the anesthesia, he developed a cardiac arrest, possibly related to significantly depressed ventricular function and severe AR. His chest was opened immediately via a full sternotomy; heparin was administered and after opening the pericardium, his aorta and right atrium were cannulated to establish cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). On bypass, the heart was electively fibrillated. After cross-clamping the distal ascending aorta and opening the aorta by means of transverse aortotomy, cold blood cardioplegia was administered antegrade into the coronary ostia. The patient was cooled to 25°C. Inspection of the aortic root revealed a large aneurysm at the level of the right SV with stratified vegetation and evidence of contained rupture communicating with the right ventricle close to the PVSD. The other sinuses looked normal. There was also a perforation of the right coronary leaflet of the aortic valve with no vegetation.

The PVSD was approached through the aorta and was closed directly using 4/0 polypropylene suture. The aortic valve and the rest of the root was excised and replaced completely with a 21-mm homograft with coronary button reimplantation. Prior to weaning from CPB, an intraaortic balloon pump was inserted.

Postoperatively, the patient was ventilated for five days and required hemofiltration for a week. However, he recovered fully without any apparent neurological deficit. Methicillin-sensitive S aureus (MSSA) was isolated from his blood cultures and valve specimen and he was continued on long-term intravenous antibiotics. Serial postoperative transthoracic echocardiographic studies showed stable position and adequate function of the homograft valve. There was no evidence of residual vegetations, or residual VSD, but impaired LV function continued to be present. While recovering, he developed a tonic-colonic seizure. Computed tomography (CT) imaging of the brain showed small biparieto-occipital subdural collections, thought likely due to septic emboli. However, further CT scan of chest/abdomen and pelvis did not show any abnormalities and it was believed that these emboli might have been from the original valvular vegetation. They were managed conservatively and no further episodes of seizure developed. His echocardiogram prior to discharge showed stable homograft valve function, no residual vegetations, no residual VSD, but persistently impaired LV function. He was discharged home on long-term antibiotic treatment and antiepileptic medication to have medical follow-up in the cardiology and infectious disease departments.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Aneurysms of the SV are rare but can be associated with other cardiac abnormalities such as VSD. 1 Patients with small VSDs (Qp: Qs ratios <1.5) are often managed with medical observation, as many small defects close spontaneously, and some that persist are associated with only mild hemodynamic abnormalities. 5 Patients with persistent VSD should be monitored with periodic surveillance examinations and echocardiograms, checking for evidence of LV volume overload from left-to-right shunt or progressive aortic valve dysfunction. In the presence of such findings, operation is indicated. 6 The VSDs are thought to be related to incomplete fusion between the right and the left distal bulbous septum in the fetus, which may ultimately be associated with weakness along the aortic annulus. 7 Therefore, the AR can be expected due to the weakness in the aortic annulus which leads to the development of aneurysm of the sinus, and second the Venturi effect and high-flow velocity in the right ventricular outflow tract, which may pull the adjacent aortic valve leaflet toward the shunt, resulting in aortic valve incompetence. 8 Once AR has developed, the risk of infective endocarditis will increase.

In the literature, there are reports of untreated PVSD and unrecognized aneurysms of SV resulting in deleterious complications such as rupture or pseudorupture of the sinus into the right ventricle, AR, and acute endocarditis. 9 –11 In our case, a small VSD which had been diagnosed in childhood and left untreated was eventually associated with MSSA endocarditis and an acute and catastrophic complication. The MSSA septicaemia is associated with a high mortality/morbidity, especially when associated with native valve endocarditis and is often complicated by abscess formation at distal sites. Except for his PVSD and the sinus aneurysm, he did not have any other risk factors for MSSA bacteraemia such as diabetes, intravenous drug use, and skin or soft tissue infections. 6

We conclude that leaving a VSD untreated can occasionally result in catastrophic complications such as acute endocarditis, acute AR, and ruptured aneurysm of the SV. In cases of severe cardiac complications or embolic events, especially with aggressive microorganisms such as S aureus, an urgent cardiac surgery is recommended. The potential for such complications must be weighed in the decision to postpone or entirely avoid surgery in patients with small to moderate size VSDs.
